title: Did the Greek gods exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: Since the victors write the history, I tend to be skeptical of all historical accounts prior to the Renaissance period. The American educational method is to teach history in a linear fashion, citing events and years, but to obtain a full picture I try to view history as a puzzle with pieces that need to be put together. How do you piece your puzzles together? One viewpoint? One source? I like going “off-script” at times, on certain subjects when I feel it is warranted. After studying the Classics, and sourcing information from multiple sources, I tend to believe the Greek Gods were not mythological. Timaeus/Critias Quotes  A Dweller on Two Planets Published in 1894   Why? In short, for the same reason in the bible that every other chapter an angel is around every corner. In the very ancient world, angelic forces interacted with mankind much more frequently. What are the names of the angels in the Bible? In a “pure” academic sense, I connect Plato’s dots. Most historians agree Plato absolutely did exist and he writes about a landmass called Atlantis. Decide for Yourself: Is Atlantis Real or Fiction? I don’t think Plato was making up fiction. According to Plato and later many so called mystics, Atlantis was at one time a very technologically advanced society, but according to accounts they abused their power to such an extent they destroyed themselves. What exactly were they doing? They had decoded the human genome far surpassing our present knowledge, and were experimenting and then breeding chimeras, half man half beasts, mixing the sacred, with the foul etc.  Theseus Killing the Minotaur  Piecing all of it together using multiple sources, I think the Greek “Gods” did exist. Another example might be the “tales” of Giants in the ancient world. Opening the mind, stretching the mind, and sourcing information from multiple sources off the academia only “map”, it becomes clear that it would be very difficult for certain things to “not” have existed and transpired. 3,000-year-old artifacts reveal history behind biblical David and Goliath It was a much different world back then.  Giants are mentioned in the Bible in several places (e.g., Genesis 6:4; Joshua 12:4). Og, king of Bashan (Deuteronomy 3:11); the giant people in Canaan that Moses’ spies reported (Numbers 13:30–33); Goliath (2 Samuel 21:19); and the Anakites (Deuteronomy 9:1–2) are all examples of giants in Scripture Yet it was I who destroyed the Amorite before them, whose height was like the height of the cedars, and he was as strong as the oaks; yet I destroyed his fruit above and his roots beneath. Also it was I who brought you up from the land of Egypt, and led you forty years through the wilderness, to possess the land of the Amorite Amos 2:9–10 The Emim had dwelt there in times past, a people as great and numerous and tall as the Anakim. They were also regarded as giants [Hebrew rephaim], like the Anakim, but the Moabites call them Emim Deuteronomy 2:10–11

Well I can probably say that yes they are I have such an account of these gods with Indians Well before Alexander the great there was another great warrior who tried to invade whole world and this time he was none other than son of Greek God Zeus son Dionysus. Dionysus’s last big adventure on earth, before he became a full-time god: he decided to invade India. Why? Why not? He had traveled all over the Mediterranean and into Egypt and Syria, but whenever he tried to spread the good news about wine farther east, he always got stopped by angry locals. Maybe that’s because Mesopotamia was where they invented beer. Maybe they didn’t want any beverage competition. Anyway, he decided to make one final push to expand his market share. As far asthe Greeks were concerned, India was pretty much the end of the world, so Dionysus decided to go there, take over, teach them about wine, and come back home, preferably in time for supper. His drunken followers gathered by the thousands. Some stories say that Hercules joined Dionysus for the expedition, and they had some major drinking contests along the way. Other stories say that the twin sons of Hephaestus, the Kabeiroi, rode into battle on a mechanical chariot and fought bravely. A couple of times, they got a little too brave and were surrounded by enemies, at which point Hephaestus himself had to come down, spray the enemy with his divine flamethrower, and bring his kids back tosafety. Dionysus rode at the head of his army in a golden chariot pulled by two centaurs. A lot of towns surrendered to him in Syria. The drunken army made it all the way to the Euphrates River and constructed a bridge to get them across— the first time Greeks had gotten that far. The bridge isn’t there anymore. What did you expect? It was made by a bunch of drunks. It probably fell apart in about a week. Everything was going great—until the army reached India. Those Indians knew how to fight. They had their own magic, their own gods, their own bunch of nasty secret weapons. Their holy men, the Brahmans, would sit on the field of battlelooking all peaceful, and Dionysus’s army would roll up, thinking the enemy was surrendering. As soon as the Greeks got close, the Indians would fire rockets into their midst—jets of flame and blinding light, massive explosions that caused panic in the troops. After a bunch of tough battles, Dionysus finally made it to the Ganges River, which was the holy river of India. He assaulted one last fortress—a big castle on a hill as tall as the Acropolis back in Athens. His centaurs and satyrs tried a frontal assault, climbing up the rocks, but the Indians set off some magic explosions that were so powerful the Greek front lines were vaporized. Supposedly you can still see theafterimages of satyrs and centaurs burned into the cliffs where the battle happened. At that point, Dionysus decided enough was enough. They’d made it to India. They’d introduced wine. Dionysus had collected a sweet assortment of exotic predator cats, like tigers and leopards. He’d even taken the leopard as his new sacred animal and started a fashion craze by wearing a leopard skin as a cape. The army had taken a lot of treasure. They’d met new and interesting people, killed most of them, and generally had a good time. Dionysus built a pair of pillars on the banks of the Ganges to prove that he’d been there. He bade the Indians a tearful farewell and marched back to Greece. Hedropped off a load of treasure at the Oracle of Delphi in honor of the gods, and for a long time, there used to big silver bowl in the Delphic treasure room inscribed: TAKEN FROM THE INDIANS BY DIONYSUS, SON OF ZEUS AND SEMELE. Well that is all that I know. I hope it will be helpful as it proves that both Hinduism and Greek religions were true. I also think that it is a quite disappointing thing that even after winning such a great war we didn't even care to know about it. I hope it is helpful. Thanks

It seems I’m the first one to post a sane answer to this question- No, the Greek gods do not exist, no gods exist. That is the only rational conclusion not simply because of the lack of evidence, but because of the EXTREME lack of evidence, considering the concept of “gods”. I can’t conclude an asteroid the size of a baseball did not hit the Earth last Tuesday simply because of the lack of evidence, because I could have missed a report, or it could have happened somewhere unnoticed. I CAN conclude an asteroid the size of Michigan did not hit the Earth last Tuesday because of the lack of evidence. What is the difference? Something as huge as that would not go unnoticed. If there was anything that was even remotely worthy of the word “god” to describe what it is, we would have noticed it- just like all the people in the Greek Myths saw and interacted with the Gods all the time.

That's up there with "does God exist?" Which can not really be answered as while no evidence shows that a god or gods exist, there isn't any evidence to show they can't. However as a Hellenic polytheist I believe they do exist but I can not know for sure, nor can I provide any kind of testable proof. Nor do I think anyone should just take my word for it. As a polytheist I generally believe all gods exist unless I have a reason not to. As a result while I believe in Zeus, I do believe that Iovis Pater is not a seperate god but the same one just understood by a different culture. O believe that Athena and Minerva are the same goddess, as are Hecate and Angelos, or Hermes, Mercurius, and Thoth.

Probably not. I want to go ahead and warn people, I am an Atheist and I might accidentally insult religions, sorry in advance. Okay, so, Greek gods. 12 Olympians, more primordial deities, a few titans and a shitton of minor gods. Did they exist? I don't think so, however, if I had to believe in one religion, it would be this one. That sounds weird, but hear me out. What seems more logical, one all-loving, all-knowing God who let's us wage war and destroy ourselves, or 12 major gods, none of which are all-knowing or all-powerful. They fight among themselves, they let humans wage war in their name. Ares even is the god of war, he is stronger when there is war, so of course he wouldn't interfere.

Yes , Greek gods are a reality. According to the legends , a god needs to be completely forgotten by the people to fade away. And this is not possible as we have named various products after the name of the god so they cannot be forgotten completely. The name of various elements and medicines are derived from Greek words . So we recall the name of the gods accidentally in our day to day life. It is up to one's believe weather they believe in god or not. If u believe in god they do exist else doesn't exist. Greek mythology is one of the oldest mythologies and it has its own followers. Since there are people who believes in old legends and the stories , the God exists . Mythology means that the stories mentioned in the books had taken place but there is no proof that they happened. But there have always been believers of those deities . All the gods have their temples and people worship them . Those people who worship them do believe in their existence . So yes the gods do exist and they would continue to exist till their existence is being remembered. And yes Greek gods are a reality.

They have certainly been around and studied for a very long time and there are still a few people in Greece who continue to worship them. They live on in the arts, in the planets and through astrology. The stories of their goings on serves in the same way as the parables did in the New Testament, that is to say lessons in how to behave (or not) in daily life. This was already a major subject in The Laws by Plato in the chapter on Religion which includes an »Address to the Young Heretic » from which I should like to quote the following: « The most important of all, however lightly you take it at the moment, is to get the right ideas about the gods and so live a good life - otherwise you’ll live a bad one. » This is taken from Penguin Classics ‘Plato The Laws translated by T.J. Saunders first published in 1970

If you mean ‘was there ever a ruler called something like Zeus who headed a prehistoric tribe in the Balkan area?’, the answer is that we simply don’t know, but it’s not unlikely. But if you mean ‘were there flying superheroes with magical weapons hanging around with human beings at the time of the Trojan War?’ then the answer is pretty clearly no. If there had been, we would have much more numerous and detailed accounts of their interventions than we do.

For those who work with them they answer prayer and heal minds. Prayers to the Greek Gods, particularly Apollo, don’t focus on sin, but on health, seeing that errors in judgement and mindset often cause pain, injury, and illness. They ask that the mind may be cleared so that the natural processes can heal the body. As for making them “aliens” like Thor and Marvel Comics, Star Trek stories posited their being such beings that came to earth, but that’s another fiction altogether. I work with Greek priestesses and priests and as a chaplain, for those who are called to faith in them, they are real. The Gods and Goddesses call their followers as much as the God of the Hebrews and Jesus.

Did the Greek Gods exist? Well, it’s hard to say. It really depends on your beliefs. If you are pagan, or someone who believes in the Greek Gods, then yes. If you don’t, then no. From a purely theoretical lens, the Greek Gods did and did not exist, depending on your beliefs and thought process. For the Ancient Greeks, they surely did exist as much as I or you do.

This is a great question. You could write books trying to answer this. The first thing to do though (to avoid writing a book for any answer): define “reality”. real as in my cat is here, Zeus is just around the corner parking his bikereal as in they are valid gods that people worship stillreal as in they are valid gods that people used to worshipreal as in the writings about them are authentic, not forgedreal as in constructs of the mind…
Q. Did the Greek gods exist? In my opinion, they existed every bit as much as the Roman gods, the Norse gods, and the Christian gods.

The thing is there's a fine line between myth and reality. One thing for sure Human mind might be capable of imagination, but conjuring up the crazy world of Greek gods and monsters is still a task. So they must have been passed through generations of what might have happened in a grand manner. So unless and until we go back to that time we can't say for sure whether the Greek gods are real or not!!!
Yes, as much as the Christian God, the Jewish God, the Muslim God, the Roman Gods, the Nordic Gods, the Celtic Gods, and so on.
Did Greek gods really exist? Yes, in people’s imaginations, just like the “God” of the bible. God is Imaginary - 50 simple proofs

They're archetypal/anthropomorphic/symbolic representations of abstract concepts, hypothetical constructs, forces of nature etc - Aphrodite/Venus being the embodiment of Beauty & Love - a beautiful woman.Ares/Mars being the embodiment of war/combat/rage - a powerful warrior.Hera/Juno - Mother archetype.Zeus/Jupiter - Father archetype. Dionysus/Bacchus - embodiment of partying.I don't think Ancient Greeks took them 100% literally, nor did they dismiss them as purely symbolic - certain ideas exist beyond ourselves in all people - so this is how they were represented in their culture. My answer is not definitive.

According to reality, no objective evidence for existence of any God exists, Greek or some other. According to current day Hellenists, yes they do exist. According to classical era Mediterranean civilizations of grecoroman descent, yes they exist. They saw Gods as immortal beings.

The belief and influence the Greeks gods had was very real and we see a lot of it in our culture today. As for the gods themselves, they have proven to be just as real as any other. For that is why we say we believe in god/s and not just accept them as facts.
The Greek gods were as real as any gods ih the history of humans. There is as much proof of the Greek gods' existence as there is proof of the existence of any God(s).

The culture and legends of ancient Greece have a remarkably long legacy in the modern language of education, politics, philosophy, art and science. Classical references from thousands of years ago continue to appear. But what was the origin of some of these ideas?
No. They were imaginary just like ALL other gods of both other past religions and current ones.
If your able to believe in god then you should also believe in the greek gods. gods are tools they have their purpose
for the greeks the greek gods were very real ergo they existed the gods did not have to be of flesh and blood e b
